t: Luke 15
The Parable of the Lost Sheep
Then*p all the tax collectors and the sinners drew near to Him to hear Him.
And the Pharisees and scribes complained, saying, “This Man receives sinners and eats with them.”
So He spoke this parable to them, saying:

“What*rp man*r of*r you,*r having*r a*r hundred*r sheep,*r if*r he*r loses*r one*r of*r them,*r does*r not*r leave*r the*r ninety-nine*r in*r the*r wilderness,*r and*r go*r after*r the*r one*r which*r is*r lost*r until*r he*r finds*r it?*r
And*r when*r he*r has*r found*r it,*ir he*r lays*r it*ir on*r his*r shoulders,*r rejoicing.*r

And*r when*r he*r comes*r home,*r he*r calls*r together*r his*ir friends*r and*r neighbors,*r saying*r to*r them,*r ‘Rejoice*r with*r me,*r for*r I*r have*r found*r my*r sheep*r which*r was*r lost!’*r

I*r say*r to*r you*r that*r likewise*r there*r will*r be*r more*r joy*r in*r heaven*r over*r one*r sinner*r who*r repents*r than*r over*r ninety-nine*r just*r persons*r who*r need*r no*r repentance.*r
The Parable of the Lost Coin

“Or*rp what*r woman,*r having*r ten*r silver*r coins,*r if*r she*r loses*r one*r coin,*r does*r not*r light*r a*r lamp,*r sweep*r the*r house,*r and*r search*r carefully*r until*r she*r finds*r it?*ir
And*r when*r she*r has*r found*r it,*ir she*r calls*r her*ir friends*r and*r neighbors*r together,*r saying,*r ‘Rejoice*r with*r me,*r for*r I*r have*r found*r the*r piece*r which*r I*r lost!’*r
Likewise,*r I*r say*r to*r you,*r there*r is*r joy*r in*r the*r presence*r of*r the*r angels*r of*r God*r over*r one*r sinner*r who*r repents.”*r
The Parable of the Lost Son
Then*p He said: “A*r certain*r man*r had*r two*r sons.*r
And*r the*r younger*r of*r them*r said*r to*r his*ir father,*r ‘Father,*r give*r me*r the*r portion*r of*r goods*r that*r falls*r to*ir me.’*ir So*r he*r divided*r to*r them*r his*ir livelihood.*r
And*r not*r many*r days*r after,*r the*r younger*r son*r gathered*r all*r together,*r journeyed*r to*r a*r far*r country,*r and*r there*r wasted*r his*r possessions*r with*r prodigal*r living.*r
But*r when*r he*r had*r spent*r all,*r there*r arose*r a*r severe*r famine*r in*r that*r land,*r and*r he*r began*r to*r be*r in*r want.*r
Then*r he*r went*r and*r joined*r himself*r to*r a*r citizen*r of*r that*r country,*r and*r he*r sent*r him*r into*r his*r fields*r to*r feed*r swine.*r
And*r he*r would*r gladly*r have*r filled*r his*r stomach*r with*r the*r pods*r that*r the*r swine*r ate,*r and*r no*r one*r gave*r him*r anything.*ir
“But*rp when*r he*r came*r to*r himself,*r he*r said,*r ‘How*r many*r of*r my*r father’s*r hired*r servants*r have*r bread*r enough*r and*r to*r spare,*r and*r I*r perish*r with*r hunger!*r
I*r will*r arise*r and*r go*r to*r my*r father,*r and*r will*r say*r to*r him,*r “Father,*r I*r have*r sinned*r against*r heaven*r and*r before*r you,*r
and*r I*r am*r no*r longer*r worthy*r to*r be*r called*r your*r son.*r Make*r me*r like*r one*r of*r your*r hired*r servants.”’*r

“And*rp he*r arose*r and*r came*r to*r his*r father.*r But*r when*r he*r was*r still*r a*r great*r way*r off,*r his*r father*r saw*r him*r and*r had*r compassion,*r and*r ran*r and*r fell*r on*r his*r neck*r and*r kissed*r him.*r
And*r the*r son*r said*r to*r him,*r ‘Father,*r I*r have*r sinned*r against*r heaven*r and*r in*r your*r sight,*r and*r am*r no*r longer*r worthy*r to*r be*r called*r your*r son.’*r
“But*rp the*r father*r said*r to*r his*r servants,*r ‘Bring*r out*r the*r best*r robe*r and*r put*r it*ir on*r him,*r and*r put*r a*r ring*r on*r his*r hand*r and*r sandals*r on*r his*ir feet.*r
And*r bring*r the*r fatted*r calf*r here*r and*r kill*r it,*ir and*r let*r us*r eat*r and*r be*r merry;*r
for*r this*r my*r son*r was*r dead*r and*r is*r alive*r again;*r he*r was*r lost*r and*r is*r found.’*r And*r they*r began*r to*r be*r merry.*r
“Now*rp his*r older*r son*r was*r in*r the*r field.*r And*r as*r he*r came*r and*r drew*r near*r to*r the*r house,*r he*r heard*r music*r and*r dancing.*r
So*r he*r called*r one*r of*r the*r servants*r and*r asked*r what*r these*r things*r meant.*r
And*r he*r said*r to*r him,*r ‘Your*r brother*r has*r come,*r and*r because*r he*r has*r received*r him*r safe*r and*r sound,*r your*r father*r has*r killed*r the*r fatted*r calf.’*r
“But*rp he*r was*r angry*r and*r would*r not*r go*r in.*r Therefore*r his*r father*r came*r out*r and*r pleaded*r with*r him.*r

So*r he*r answered*r and*r said*r to*r his*ir father,*r ‘Lo,*r these*r many*r years*r I*r have*r been*r serving*r you;*r I*r never*r transgressed*r your*r commandment*r at*r any*r time;*r and*r yet*r you*r never*r gave*r me*r a*r young*r goat,*r that*r I*r might*r make*r merry*r with*r my*r friends.*r
But*r as*r soon*r as*r this*r son*r of*r yours*r came,*r who*r has*r devoured*r your*r livelihood*r with*r harlots,*r you*r killed*r the*r fatted*r calf*r for*r him.’*r
“And*rp he*r said*r to*r him,*r ‘Son,*r you*r are*r always*r with*r me,*r and*r all*r that*r I*r have*r is*r yours.*r
It*r was*r right*r that*r we*r should*r make*r merry*r and*r be*r glad,*r for*r your*r brother*r was*r dead*r and*r is*r alive*r again,*r and*r was*r lost*r and*r is*r found.’”*r
